title-group.article-title: Using a Theorem by Andersen and the Dichotomous Rasch Model to Assess the Presence of Random Guessing in Multiple Choice Items

abstract.p: Andersen (1995, 2002) proves a theorem relating variances of parameter estimates from samples and subsamples and shows its use as an adjunct to standard statistical analyses. The authors show an application where the theorem is central to the hypothesis tested, namely, whether random guessing to multiple choice items affects their estimates in the Rasch model. Taking random guessing to be a function of the difficulty of an item relative to the proficiency of a person, the authors describe a method for creating a subsample of responses, which is least likely to be affected by guessing. Then using Andersen’s theorem, the authors assess the difference in difficulty estimates between responses from the whole sample and the subsample for each item. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the procedure, data are simulated according to a class of models in which random guessing is a function of the proficiency of a person relative to the difficulty of an item. The procedure is also applied to an empirical data set from Raven’s Advanced Progressive Matrices, with the results indicating that guessing is present in a substantial number of items. It is noted that one especially important application in which estimating the correct relative difficulty of items is required is where the items will form part of an item bank and where on subsequent occasions the items will be administered interactively. In this case, items too difficult for a person are not administered and therefore unlikely to attract random guessing.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Andersen (1995, 2002) proves a theorem that relates the variance of the estimates of parameters from a sample of responses to estimates of the same parameters from independent subsamples of these responses. Andersen provides examples of the use of this theorem in the context of both psychometrics and standard analysis of variance contexts as adjuncts to more traditional analyses of data. In this article, we present a study in which this theorem is not merely an adjunct to other analyses, but is central to it. The study is concerned with identifying the presence of random guessing in multiple choice items, which assess proficiency using the dichotomous Rasch (1960) model. Random guessing of a correct response, developed further in the paper, is considered likely to be present primarily as a function of the proficiency of a person relative to the difficulty of an item, rather than a property of an item per se.

There is no guessing parameter for an item in the dichotomous Rasch model, only a person proficiency parameter and an item difficulty parameter. Therefore, it is expected that if there is guessing in the responses, then the estimates of the item parameters will be affected by the guessing. However, there are reasons for applying this model, rather than one that includes a guessing parameter for each item. One reason is that if the data fit the model, then the item difficulty estimates can be obtained independent of any assumptions of the distribution of the relevant class of persons who respond to the items. The consequent advantages are that unweighted scores are used, and, because only item difficulties are required, application to adaptive assessment using item banks is relatively simple. In addition, in an adaptive design in which person proficiencies are aligned with item difficulties, guessing should be minimized. Such adaptive testing is also referred to as tailored testing, and we use the latter term in the article. There are many examples in educational and psychological assessment where the Rasch model is applied to responses collected from multiple choice items, and to tailored testing.

Our application of Andersen’s theorem initially involves two analyses. In the first analysis, we estimate the parameters from a sample of responses. In the second, we estimate the same parameters from a subsample of these responses. The first analysis is a typical analysis of a set of responses, some of which are affected by random guessing. We call this simply the first analysis of any data set. Guessing on an item generates more correct responses than there would be otherwise. Then because the total number of correct responses is a sufficient statistic for the estimate of the item parameter in the Rasch model, guessing in the responses to an item in the first analysis makes it appear relatively easier than it would be otherwise.

A person who does not know the correct answer, and provides a response, either guesses randomly among all response alternatives or first eliminates one or more of the response alternatives based on partial knowledge, and then selects randomly from the remainder. We do not distinguish between partial and no knowledge and refer to such guessing as random guessing. Then following Waller (1973, 1976, 1989), we take random guessing to be a function of the proficiency of a person relative to the difficulty of an item; the lower the relative proficiency, the greater the probability of random guessing.

The second analysis involves a subset of responses in which a strategy is employed to remove those responses most likely to be affected by guessing. Specifically, based on the first analysis, if the proficiency of a person relative to the difficulty of an item is such that random guessing increases the probability of a correct response beyond an amount specified by the analyst, then that response is removed and treated as a missing response. This has the same effect as if the item was not administered to the person because it was considered too difficult, a procedure often referred to as tailored testing. Accordingly, the second analysis is referred to as a tailored analysis. It is expected that those items in which guessing is present will have a relatively greater difficulty in the tailored than in the first analysis.

This approach was also used by Waller, but whereas he considered the effects on the person parameter estimates, we focus on the item parameter estimates using Andersen’s theorem which was not available to Waller. We return to mention further studies on effects of guessing on the person parameters. Because a conditional method of estimating the item parameters is applied (Andersen, 1973), no assumptions regarding the distribution of person proficiencies are made. Therefore, the item difficulties are the sole parameters estimated from the sample of responses.

To illustrate the application of the procedure described in this article, responses of persons to the Advanced Raven’s Progressive Matrices (ARPM) test are used (Raven, 1940). The ARPM is a 36 item, nonverbal test of reasoning in which each item has a two dimensional matrix with a pattern in which the element in the lower right-hand corner, which completes the pattern, is missing. From six or eight alternatives, the respondent is required to choose one to complete the pattern. With so many alternatives, it might be expected that there is little random guessing. However, the items are relatively difficult for any population, and this suggests that there might be random guessing. Responses from this test are used illustratively for two purposes: first to guide the choice of parameters to generate a simulated example; second to illustrate how to identify those items that might show evidence of guessing. The simulated example, in which the item parameters are known, is used to confirm the accuracy of the proposed procedure in identifying random guessing.

The rest of the article is structured as follows. Section 2 summarizes the dichotomous Rasch model and the rationale for inferring the presence of random guessing; Section 3 summarizes Andersen’s theorem; Section 4 derives a class of models that might be identified with guessing as a function of the proficiency of a person relative to the difficulty of an item, of which the familiar three parameter logistic (3PL) model with a guessing parameter is a special case; Section 5 describes the simulation algorithm and design; Section 6 describes the simulated example that verifies the applicability of the proposed procedure for identifying items with random guessing; Section 7 describes the analysis of the relatively difficult test, the ARPM; and Section 8 is a summary and discussion.

The case for the model is that when data fit the model within a specified frame of reference of a class of persons and a class of items, which is always an empirical question, comparisons of persons are invariant with respect to subsets of items, and vice versa. Within the Rasch measurement paradigm, misfit between the data and the model is seen as an anomaly in the data (Andrich, 2004). According to this paradigm, if possible, new data are collected by removing the sources of the anomalies, while maintaining substantive validity, so that the data conform better to the model. In the case of random guessing to multiple choice items, to remove the source of anomalies requires better alignment of the difficulty of the items to the proficiencies of the persons. The most efficient way to achieve this is using interactive, tailored testing in which only items that are neither too difficult nor too easy are administered to a person. Consistent with this paradigm, it is suggested that if guessing is provoked in persons who have reasonable proficiency beyond that which can be explained by random error already built into the Rasch model, then perhaps the item has a flaw which needs correcting. Such a flaw can only be identified on a case-by-case basis with focused qualitative analysis guided by the statistical analysis which exposes the anomalies.

In establishing the relative difficulty of items for subsequent use in tailored assessment, aligning persons and items is not always immediately possible. Therefore, in constructing item sets and establishing their relative difficulty estimates, it is important to check for the presence of guessing and to obtain relative difficulty estimates that are uncontaminated by it.

sec.title: 2.1. Effect of Guessing on the Estimates and on the ICC
sec.p:
With guessing by less proficient persons, the number of persons who answer an item correctly is greater than it would be without guessing. sec.title: 3.1. A Common Identifying Constraint in the First and Tailored Analyses
sec.p:
Andersen applied the theorem above in contexts in which he considered estimates from different groups simultaneously. However, we wish to identify individual items that show differences in their estimates between the first and tailored analyses. We therefore need to take account of a required identifying constraint in the item difficulty estimates. In particular in the software used, and in common with many approaches, the mean of the item difficulty estimates sums to zero:

If every analysis of the sample and subsamples of data have this identifying constraint, then to demonstrate changes in difficulty of individual items requires a step not taken by Andersen in his examples. The reason the step is necessary is that because each analysis has the same identifying constraint of

Below we describe a rationale for fixing the mean of the estimates of a subset of the easiest items from the tailored analysis in a third analysis. We do not fix the difficulty of just one item, such as the easiest item, because in principle this is less stable than fixing the mean of more than one item. We chose to fix the mean of as many items as we consider did not show guessed responses. This choice is commented upon further in the article.

First, by its construction, it is anticipated that the item difficulty estimates in the tailored analysis will be less affected by guessing than the first analysis. Second, it is anticipated that the easiest of these items will be the least affected by guessing. Therefore, the difficulty estimates of a small subset of relatively easy items in the tailored analysis are used to impose the necessary identifying constraint. In particular, the mean of their estimates is fixed. Specifically, in the example in this article, we fix the mean of the difficulties of the six easiest items in the tailored analysis to provide the identifying constraint in reanalyzing the complete set of responses. That is, in both the tailored analysis and in the reanalysis of the complete set of responses, the identifying constraint is that the average of the item difficulties of six easy items is the same. Then, apart from this constraint on the six items, all items, including these six, have new estimates whose relative locations are entirely determined by the original data. Because fixing the identifying constraint in this way is typically referred to as anchoring item difficulties, this analysis is referred to as the anchored analysis. It complements the first and the tailored analyses. We note that, for purposes of stability of the constraint, the mean location of as many items as possible that are easy enough to be considered unaffected by guessing should be used as the identifying constraint.

Because a complete set of responses is used in the anchored analysis, the difficulty estimates will be affected by any guessing. The items that have correct guesses in their responses should be relatively easier than in the tailored analysis. However, in this case, the items that have no guessing should not be affected artificially by the identifying constraint, which is the same in the tailored and anchored analyses. It is hypothesized that if guessing is present in the responses of the lower proficiency students to a given item, then that item’s difficulty will be greater in the anchored analysis than in the tailored analysis.

Existing software is now available that provides conditional ML estimates in which no person distribution is assumed, and estimates of the asymptotic variance of these estimates are available. This conditional estimation is sufficiently well developed in the literature that it is not repeated in this article. Through a simulation example with no guessing, we confirm the accuracy of the procedure in detecting changes in the estimates. The detection rate is that which would be expected by chance.

sec.title: 5. Simulation Algorithm and Design
sec.p:
Equation (8) was used to simulate guessing as a function of proficiency. The value for the power
y
was chosen to approximate the evidence from the ARPM data based on the following rationale. In Figure 1 referred to earlier, which shows the ICCs for ARPM test items which were hypothesized to have guessing, the proportion of persons who answered an item correctly for class intervals with mean location of persons below approximately −1.0 were greater than the ICC. The grouping of persons in class intervals blurs the specific details of guessing, but relative to a mean item difficulty of 0, which was the identifying constraint, we take −1.0 logits as a reference for guessing to an item with a difficulty of 1 logit. Guessing is not evident at an item difficulty of 0. Thus, guessing is evident for persons with proficiency 2 logits below the item’s difficulty, which according to the Rasch model corresponds with a probability of just 0.12 of a correct response.

A choice of
y = 15

The tailored analysis of the empirical example had 36 items with the last item so difficult that all persons were eliminated. Therefore, only 35 items were used in all the analyses and in the simulated response set. Because the tailored analysis was considered to provide estimates least affected by guessing for all parameters, the estimates from the tailored analysis were used as the parameters for the simulated example. Specifically, the item difficulties approximated the estimates, and the person distribution, assumed to be normal, approximated the estimates of the mean and standard deviation (SD). Although the simulated person distribution was made normal because of its general shape in the ARPM data, as indicated above, the Rasch analysis of the data did not impose any shape on the person distribution in any of the analyses.

Table 2 shows the relevant summary of the empirical estimates from the tailored analysis and the properties of the parameters in the simulated example in which the estimates are used as the parameters. For completeness, the summary statistics from the first analysis are also shown. It is evident that, as expected, the variances of the item and person parameters are smaller in the first analysis than in the tailored analysis, and smaller than those of the generating parameters. This regression is an effect of guessing where the difficulty estimates of the more difficult items are regressed to the mean of the difficulties of all items. As a result, the variance of the person estimates is also smaller in the first analysis than in the tailored analysis.

sec.title: 6.2. The Accuracy of the Estimates in the Tailored Analysis
sec.p:
Second, we consider the accuracy of the tailored analysis, which provides the opportunity to estimate the item locations with the effects of guessing minimized, and perhaps even eliminated. Figure 4 shows the item estimates from the tailored analysis plotted against simulated item locations. It also shows estimates from the anchored analysis plotted against the simulated values. sec.title: 6.3. Illustrating the Application of Andersen’s Theorem in the Case of No Guessing
sec.p: Before reporting the formal assessment of guessing in the simulated example, the results of a preliminary, simulated example with no guessing are summarized. This example is provided to illustrate and confirm the accuracy of the distribution of errors according to Andersen’s theorem in the case that there is no guessing. This confirmation is reassuring when evidence of guessing is indicated by the application of the same theorem. The example used had the same parameter specifications as those in Table 2, except that no item had guessing, and items fitted the Rasch model of Equation (1). The same procedure for testing the significance of the difference between the tailored and anchored analysis was used, where in the latter analysis the mean of the estimates of the six easiest items was anchored to that of the tailored analysis. With the data fitting the Rasch model, it was expected that with 35 items, no item, or at most 1 item, might be identified as having a significant difference in item difficulty between the tailored and anchored analyses at the 1% level of significance. Indeed, no items had a significant change in difficulty, and the mean and SD of the z statistic of Equation (4) had respective values of 0.14 and 0.95 relative to theoretical values of 0 and 1, respectively. The results from this example are consistent with the standard errors of the estimates from Andersen’s theorem.

sec.title: 6.4. Testing the Hypothesis That Guessing Affects Item Difficulty Estimates
sec.p: We now consider the simulated example with guessing. With the mean of the estimates of the six easiest items anchored to their values in the tailored analysis, the anchored and tailored analyses have the same identifying constraint. Figure 4, considered earlier, shows the item estimates from the anchored analysis plotted against simulated item locations. It is evident that there is a systematic effect that makes the item estimates relatively easier in the anchored analysis as the items become more difficult. This is consistent with the simulation where guessing increased as a function of relative difficulty. The effect begins where the items have a logit value of approximately −0.7.

With the evidence from the simulated, illustrative example, we proceed to an illustrative analysis of the real example.

sec.title: 7. The ARPM Example
sec.p: We now show in parallel with the results of the simulated example the results of the analyses of the ARPM. Because we have established in the simulation that the tailored estimates recover known difficulties well, we compare the difficulty estimates from the tailored and the anchored analyses. Again, the six easiest items are fixed in the anchored analysis to their locations from the tailored analysis as the common identifying constraint.

sec.title: 7.1. A Comparison Between the Tailored and Anchored Analyses
sec.p: First, Figure 5 shows the plot of the item estimates from the anchored analysis against the tailored analysis. For comparative purposes, it also shows the same plot for the simulated example. It is evident that in both cases, the more difficult items in the tailored analysis are not as difficult in the anchored analysis. The pattern is clearer in the simulated example, as can be expected because of the mechanism used in the simulated example, but the pattern in the ARPM strongly indicates the presence of random guessing in the more difficult items.

It also shows the z value for each item from Equation (4) which is the standardized difference between the anchored and tailored difficulty estimates using Andersen’s theorem to determine the standard error for each difference. Fourteen items are identified to have a different difficulty estimate. In each case, the estimate is more difficult in the tailored analysis. We recall that in the simulated example 13 items were identified to have greater difficulty in the tailored analysis.

As in the simulated example, the mean of the item difficulty estimates in the anchored analysis (−0.39) shows that the items appear easier in the anchored analysis than in the tailored analysis, which, of course, has a mean of 0.0. Likewise, again as in the simulated example, the SD of the item difficulty estimates in the anchored analysis (1.30) is smaller than in the tailored analysis (1.71). As provided in the rationale for the three analyses, the first, the tailored and the anchored, demonstrated in the analysis of the simulated data, these changes occur because of the systematic change in the difficulties of the more difficult items in the presence of guessing.

sec.title: 8. Summary, Discussion, and Further Research
sec.p: In the article, following Waller (1973, 1976, 1989) we define random guessing to be a function of the difference between a person’s proficiency and the item’s difficulty. Because the Rasch model has no guessing parameter, and the total score of an item is the sufficient statistic for the difficulty of an item, random guessing will make items appear easier. We summarized Andersen’s theorem relating the variance of parameter estimates of a sample to the variance of the same estimates from a subsample, and adapted the theorem to construct a statistical test of whether item estimates are affected by guessing. The test involved three analyses, which we referred to as the first, tailored and anchored analyses. The first analysis was simply an analysis of original responses, which may have been affected by guessing, the tailored analysis involved a subsample of responses in which, based on the first analysis, responses with random guessing were removed, and the anchored analysis was of the original responses but with an identifying constraint obtained from the tailored analysis. This constraint in the anchored analysis was the mean of the difficulties of a small set of easy items. The same identifying constraint permitted the estimates from the first and tailored analyses to be placed on the same scale with the same origin.

To illustrate the identification of guessing in the proposed way, responses of items from a relatively difficult test, the ARPM, were analyzed and guessing in a substantial number of items identified. To confirm the viability of the approach, a simulated example that mirrored the real data, and in which random guessing was a function of the proficiency of a person relative to the difficulty of an item, was generated and results analyzed. The results of the simulated example did, as expected, mirror that of the ARPM. In summary, (a) the tailored analysis recovered the simulated locations, and (b) the application of Andersen’s theorem identified the majority of items, especially the more difficult items, whose responses were most affected by guessing.

One application of the Rasch model where obtaining the correct, relative difficulty of items is important is where in future applications, the items will form part of an item bank and the items will be administered interactively and adaptively. In this application, items that are very difficult or very easy for a person will not be administered. Therefore, random guessing should be minimized, thus enhancing the applicability of the Rasch model. However, correct item difficulties are important in ensuring the accurate alignment of the difficulties of the items relative to the proficiencies of the items in such interactive assessment. In many applications, however, it is still not the case that items are administered adaptively. Nevertheless, if the Rasch model is applied to the data, it is essential to obtain estimates of item difficulties that are not contaminated by random guessing.

sec.title: 8.1. Impact of Guessing on Person Estimates
sec.p: The impact of guessing on person measurement when item difficulties from the first, tailored and anchored analyses are used is an area of further research. Waller (1973, 1976, 1989) showed effects on person estimates that are analogous to those that are expected given the impact on the items, in particular, that the estimates were regressed relative to their known values. However, since Waller’s studies, applications include large-scale assessments at national and international levels where scale values are fixed across jurisdictions or year levels through item banks, and benchmarks are set on particular scales. Hence, the relevance of focusing on effects of guessing on item difficulty estimates.

A number of issues arise, however, in person measurement from the above approach to controlling guessing. There is not space in this paper to study them. Given that the item estimates in which guessing has been removed are considered the relevant estimates, two cases for person estimates immediately distinguish themselves: one where population estimates are required; the second where individual estimates must be reported. In the latter, and for ethical and legal reasons, all responses of a person must be included in the estimates. It may be hypothesized that population estimates are best estimated from the tailored analysis. It may also be hypothesized that for individual estimates, persons of lower proficiency who guess will have greater estimates than otherwise. However, compared to having item estimates which are also affected by guessing as in the first analysis, and which therefore show difficult items to be easier than in the tailored analysis, persons of greater proficiency will also have greater estimates. With these analyses, a third common application, that of the proportion of persons below benchmarks, invites study when the above approach is taken to control the effect of guessing on item parameters. Thus the impact on person measurement in a broader context is a topic of further research, where the capacity to identify significant changes in item difficulty, which might arise from random guessing is an important element.

A fourth possibility for estimating person parameters arises, given again that the item parameters are estimated with the effect of guessing removed, that of using the model of Equation (8). Although this is possible, and is open to further research, there are two impediments. First, the actual value of
y
that might be relevant in any particular data set will need to be identified. The degree of misalignment between persons and item will govern the degree of guessing, and this particular value might be dependent on the data set. Second, in many cases, where individual estimates are required, it may be necessary to use a statistic that is a direct transformation of the total score, as in the Rasch model. Clearly, given that there is guessing in the data, person parameter estimates of the less proficient persons will be affected, and factors beyond the technical will be involved in deciding how these are obtained. Simplicity might be an important factor.

sec.title: 8.2. Anchoring Items
sec.p: It was argued that the greatest number of items that can be considered to have no guessing should be anchored in studying the effects of guessing and in establishing item parameter estimates. It may be considered that this recommendation involves substantial work. We make no apology for that recommendation. Data that arise from deliberate item construction and which will be used in important assessments for individuals or for groups, and even perhaps in policy decisions, require thorough analysis. Multiple analyses with different numbers of items anchored can be considered and results compared, until a number of easy items to be anchored can be justified. We believe we illustrated this in the example above. Second, it seems that this approach has no more, and perhaps even less, professional judgment than when the 3PL is invoked to account for guessing and in which many items in general cannot have their guessing parameter estimated and must simply be imposed.

sec.title: 8.3 Tests of Fit Before and After Controlling for Guessing
sec.p: As with not having the space to study effects on person estimates, we have not considered general tests of fit, which may be carried out before and after effects of guessing are controlled. In addition to issues of space, it would detract from the main point of the article. Nevertheless, we note that if guessing is present, then fit of the original data to the Rasch model will be compromised—the greater the impact of guessing, the greater the misfit to the model. However, to the degree that the guessing is random because of the low proficiency of the persons to the items, to that degree the misfit cannot be attributed to any deficiencies in the items, but to a deficiency in the alignment of persons to the items. Therefore, the study of fit, and the disclosure of any problems with items, we argue should be carried out based on the tailored analysis. As indicated, there is no space to carry out this in detail with the real example, and in any case, because the ARPM is secure, we could not report information on any specific item.

sec.title: 8.4. Distinguishing Between Differences in Discrimination and Guessing
sec.p: Finally, we consider one more issue briefly, that of an item’s empirical discrimination in relation to the effects of guessing. In Section 2, we argued that the presence of guessing can be hypothesized from the proportions of persons in successive class intervals who respond correctly to an item. Specifically, persons of low proficiency will have proportions greater than that of the ICC, and because of the effect on an item’s difficulty, persons of high proficiency will have proportions smaller than that of the ICC. However, this effect is identical to that which would be found if an item discriminates less than that characterized by the Rasch model. The Appendix shows additional evidence, using the ICC and the proportions of success of persons placed in class intervals, confirming that the differences in difficulty in the ARPM can be attributed to guessing, rather than to inherent differences in discrimination. However, in order not to distract from the main point, the application of Andersen’s theorem to diagnosing the possibility of guessing, this evidence is presented in the Appendix.

app.title: Appendix Item Characteristic Curves and Anchoring All Items
app.p: It will be recalled that we motivated the effect of guessing by considering the ICC, the estimates of item difficulties, and the graphical effect on the proportion of successes in class intervals relative to the ICC across the continuum. For three relatively difficult items from the ARPM, Figure 1 showed that not only did the items appear easier than they would be without guessing, but that the proportions of successes of persons in the lower proficiency range were greater than that predicted by the ICC and that the proportion of successes in the higher proficiency range was lower than that predicted by the ICC. Figure 3 showed similar effects for three relatively difficult items from the simulated example.

We now address the question of the proportion of correct responses in class intervals relative to the ICC when the difficulty estimate not affected by guessing (from the tailored analysis) is used to locate the ICC. The estimate affected by guessing is easier than that not affected, and therefore the ICC from the tailored analysis will be located further to the right-hand side than in the graphs of Figures 1 and 3. Accordingly, the proportions of successes for the lower proficiency persons will be even greater relative to the ICC than in Figures 1 and 3. On the other hand, the proportion of successes for the higher proficiency persons will be closer to the ICC.

To locate the ICC with the tailored analysis, a fourth analysis of all the responses of the simulated example and the ARPM was conducted but where all items were fixed to their tailored estimates. Thus the ICCs were placed in a more accurate location while to form the class intervals, all the responses, including the guessed ones, were retained. Figure 6 shows the results of this fourth analysis for the same items as those shown in Figures 1 and 3. It is evident that the proportion of successes relative to the ICCs is as predicted in both the ARPM and in the simulated example. Had the items had genuine differences in discrimination, then the proportions of higher proficiency persons who answered the items correctly would nevertheless be below the ICC. Thus Figure 6 confirms the presence of random guessing in items of the ARPM. It further confirms that the parameters of the simulated example, in which random guessing was generated, mirrored relatively accurately the responses of the ARPM.
